title: Enhancement and HF Doppler observations of sporadic-Eduring the solar eclipse of 22 July 2009
abstract: [1]Â The sporadic E (Es) frequently emerging in midlatitude during summer is a very special layer in the ionosphere, and its formation mechanism is different to from that of other layers. The total solar eclipse of 22 July 2009 provided a very unique opportunity to study the relationship of Es and solar radiation. During the solar eclipse day and the days before and after, the vertical incidence ionosonde was located in Wuhan to record the ionograms for this event. Two oblique incidence high-frequency radio systems were used to record the waves from Wuhan to Suzhou and from Wuhan to Huaian. The enhancement of Es during the eclipse period was observed in the vertical and oblique incidence ionograms. The quasi-periodic fluctuations in the critical frequency and Doppler frequency shift curves indicated the possible existence of the gravity waves, which may be responsible for the Es enhancement. However, we find that the enhancement occurred earlier than the appearance of gravity waves and consider that there may be other mechanisms which contribute to the observed enhancement in the ionosphere. A hypothesis is put forward that the cooling effect of the lunar shadow induced powerful airflow from the northern and southern limits of the shadow toward its center, which accelerated the irregularities in Es to produce the large-scale Doppler shift in the reflected waves and form the meridional windshear. Both the windshear and the gravity waves may affect the Es layer and increase the electron concentration. Many observed phenomena are in accordance with this.

motivations: The formation mechanism of sporadic E (Es) layers in the ionosphere is not well understood and requires further study.
The total solar eclipse of 22 July 2009 provided a unique opportunity to investigate the relationship between Es layers and solar radiation.
objectives: Investigate the enhancement of Es layers during the solar eclipse of 22 July 2009 using ionosonde and high-frequency radio systems.
Analyze the role of gravity waves and other mechanisms in the observed enhancement of Es layers.
methods: Record ionograms using vertical incidence ionosonde and oblique incidence high-frequency radio systems during the solar eclipse.
Analyze the critical frequency and Doppler frequency shift curves to identify quasi-periodic fluctuations and possible gravity waves.
results: Observed enhancement of Es layers during the solar eclipse period, possibly related to gravity waves and other mechanisms.
Proposed hypothesis that the cooling effect of the lunar shadow induces airflow and windshear, contributing to the observed enhancement.

motivations: The formation mechanism of sporadic E (Es) layers in the midlatitude ionosphere during summer is not fully understood and differs from other ionospheric layers.
Solar eclipses provide unique opportunities to study the relationship between sporadic E layers and solar radiation under controlled natural conditions.
objectives: Investigate the enhancement of sporadic E layers during the total solar eclipse of 22 July 2009 and understand its relationship with solar radiation.
Identify the mechanisms responsible for sporadic E enhancement during the eclipse, including the roles of gravity waves and atmospheric dynamics.
methods: Deploy vertical incidence ionosonde in Wuhan to record ionograms during the eclipse and surrounding days.
Use two oblique incidence high-frequency radio systems to monitor wave propagation from Wuhan to Suzhou and from Wuhan to Huaian.
Analyze quasi-periodic fluctuations in critical frequency and Doppler frequency shift to detect gravity waves and other atmospheric phenomena.
results: Enhancement of sporadic E layers was observed during the eclipse period in both vertical and oblique incidence ionograms.
The enhancement occurred earlier than gravity wave appearance, suggesting additional mechanisms such as lunar shadow-induced airflow and meridional windshear contribute to the phenomenon.
